Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Social Media during Rapid Transition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will examine the impact of online social media, when a nation first becomes open to this new technology-based form of communication. Relatively few countries in the world lack social media penetration, but from time to time additional nations offer global connectivity to their citizens. Cuban citizens will soon get dramatically more access to the Internet. How will their increased access to the global network change their view of the world? What can this teach us about the impact of social media on the developing world? What can it teach us about the impact of social media on society more generally? This kind of change forms a unique natural experiment that can reveal fundamental characteristics of social media in society.

In this work, researchers will perform in-depth, semi-structured qualitative interviews with citizens of a newly connected society about their use of social media. Interviews will be conducted in their language via text-based chat and audio (Skype and phone) wherever possible. With permission, subjects' online postings will also be analyzed. Data will be analyzed via a grounded theory approach. The research will focus on a nation where changes have not yet begun to affect ordinary citizens. As a result, the research team will be able to gain insights into pre-existing attitudes and hopes for the future. Over this critical coming year, they will be able to track how those attitudes change. This qualitative work is valuable in itself and will also form the basis for a machine learning study designed to automatically track changes in public opinion as expressed via social media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work contributes to a critical understanding of the ways users experience, appropriate, and alter information communication technologies (ICTs) in resource-constrained settings. We studied evolving internet and social media use in Cuba from 2015 to 2017, starting with a study on (1) early adopters of internet and social media in Havana and (2) the first, public WiFi hotspots in Havana (introduced in March 2016). The findings from these studies revealed that “traditional” access to the internet is severely restricted in Cuba. As a result, Cubans have developed robust, community-led  information networks that serve as alternatives to traditional internet access. Therefore, study (3) explored El Paquete Semanal, an offline, information network that supplies Cuba with local and foreign digital content. Our final study (4) examined StreetNet, a clandestine, citizen-led network that spans the city of Havana. The specific findings of each study are discussed below:

1. Early Adopters of the Internet and Social Media

Qualitative analysis of the interview data and online interactions with participants demonstrated that, at the time of our initial fieldwork in 2016, participants only had access to the internet in certain workplaces, and access limitations and slow network speeds greatly restricted Cubans’ Internet use. Participants used intermediated access techniques to counter limitations, often conducting online research and posting photos for friends with less access. In a context in which most people do not have consistent access to any kind of communications technology including telephone, intermittent access to Facebook is used for basic communication for both work and socializing. Participants with lower access reported that they rely on others to help maintain their Facebook presence, further highlighting the importance of collaborative efforts to use internet tools.  

(2) WiFi Hotspots  

The findings from this study show that more individuals are getting online in Havana through  new WiFi hotspots and many for the first time. However,  access at these spots is expensive and  slow and this limits the amount and types of activities that individuals can do online. The primary reason Cubans spend exorbitant amounts of money for short periods of slow internet access is to reconnect with strong ties--mainly family living outside of the country. The majority of Cubans are not in the position to get online regularly (if at all). Our findings provide design implications for companies, researchers, and local actors working to increase internet access in Cuba as well as among other resource-constrained communities in other parts of the world.

(3) El Paquete Semanal

Internet access in Cuba is heavily restricted. However, millions of Cubans still engage with  digital content through an informal, pervasive, offline internet known as El Paquete Semanal or  “The Weekly Package.” Every week, a new version of El Paquete (EP) becomes available, and  includes a one terabyte (TB) collection of digital content that is distributed across Cuba on external hard drives, USBs, and CDs. Not formally sanctioned by the government, EP manages  to facilitate offline access to local and international content regularly and affordably.  This  community-led information network is the primary medium by which Cubans receive and  engage with local and international media, news, and entertainment. We conducted a  qualitative inquiry of El Paquete through extensive fieldwork--interviews and observations--in  Havana, Cuba. Our findings highlight the human infrastructure (the people, relationships, and  organizations) that supports this offline internet in a technologically constrained environment  and the work that goes into sustaining this system. We offer an enriched understanding of how  an entirely offline internet can provide expansive information access to support leisure and  livelihood, additionally serving as a locally  relevant platform that affords local participation.  Our findings challenge established notions of what an (or the) internet “should” look like in  more and less “developed” contexts.

(4) StreetNet

Our final study explored StreetNet (SNET), a community-based, metropolitan area network  (MAN) located in Havana.  Currently, SNET connects more than 10,000 computers through the  use of WiFi antennas and Ethernet cables running across rooftops and streets in the city of  Havana. In response to the lack of internet access in Cuba, SNET has evolved to include its own  versions of Facebook, EBay, MUDs, private messaging, group chats, classifieds, forums, and  more. Our findings explore how users have been able to create and sustain both the digital and  physical infrastructure of this decentralized, informal internet for more than 16 years (since  2001). Similar to El Paquete, our findings offer an understanding of an internet that serves as an  alternative to the world wide web.

Overall, these findings inform the design of technological services and social media tools aimed  at addressing the values and constraints of users not only in Cuba, but in emerging economies  around the world.
